name: Mac Action Magazine
description: For about a year I wrote the US News column for Mac Action, a UK gaming and entertainment magazine for Mac users. I'm not sure my writing style ever recovered from the distinctive UK tech magazine voice: snarky editorial asides throughout otherwise vanilla content, and wry in jokes for every photo caption.

name: Kidstuff Magazine
description: The summer I turned ten, I decided to start a magazine. I wrote and published it for almost six years, and it had a pretty significant impact on the direction of my early career.

name: Eclipse News
description: I designed, edited, and wrote select feature articles for a software consultancy's client-focused newsletter. More than the usual desktop publishing work, it gave me chance to learn from subject matter experts about then-novel technologies like Apple's now defunct OpenDoc and SGML, the precursor to HTML and XML.

name: Mac Reviews Digest
description: A tech news and product reviews zine I published in SETEXT format; eventually it became my first web site.

name: Inside Mac Games
description: I wrote reviews, feature articles, and a regular "company spotlight" column for Inside Mac Games, one of the few high-circulation digital magazines that predated the web. Highlights included interviewing the Cyan Software's Miller Brothers about their breakout game, Myst, and writing one of the first sneak peek articles about a promising little game called "Fallout." It ended up doing pretty well.

name: BlackDog Bicycle Group
description: Black Dog was a forward-thinking bicycle company early to the ecommerrce scene. I wrote the bespoke "find a dearler near you" software for their site in the days when that required funky math and a licensed database of zip code lat/lon pairs, rather than a Google Maps API key.

name: Motorola
description: I spent a summar as a contract network administator at Motorola's Schaumburg campus, wrangling an organization-wide OS upgrade for several hundred Macs and writing custom tools in Hypercard to automate error-prone parts of the process.

name: Cooksoft
description: I designed the box art, wrote markting copy, and did product photography for a recipe management program that was actually sold on shelves, in CompUSA, in the days when we had shelves and CompUSAs. I distinctly remember getting a huge stack of polaroids from the client with terribly-lit photos of food. It was a different time.

name: Havana Modern
description: This attempt to build an online roleplaying game turned into a years-long exercise in recreational futurism. The project was never completed, but it gave several young nerds a platform to experiment and, importantly, brainstorm about the long-term social implications of the tech were watching emerge. In the years that followed, most of us went on to join tech companies and build permutations of the stuff we'd speculated about. Every few years we check in and have a chuckle what we got right, and what we got very, very wrong.

name: Advantage Coaching & Training
description: As part of our work with Advantage Coaching and Training, I got half a dozen sessions with one of ACT’s personal business coaches. What I learned was that my unique information processing style would benefit from a huge-ass wall of Post-Its, changing my relationship with vertical surfaces forever.

name: Brasel Products, Inc.
description: A weird combination of product photography, web design, copywriting, Novell network troubleshooting, and on-the-job sexual harassment. The perpetrator was eventually arrested for embezzlement, adding another data point to the Al Capone theory.

name: C9 Construction
description: A local construction company that came to us because the money they dumped into full-page Yellow Pages ads was no longer generating business. Remember the Yellow Pages? It was the 800lb gorilla of small business visibility for a long, long time.

name: Stones Jewelry
description: Over the course of 1998 we worked our way through the chamber of commerce, dragging local busuinesses kicking and screaming onto the internet. This jewelry store had been around for generations and was thrilled to get onto the Information Superhighway.

name: Kirkby & Associates
description: A local accounting firm we'd done copy and design work for brought us on to build their web site: it was a journey, but I finally had a good reason to use the classy "green marble" tiled GIF background I'd kept in reserve.

name: Hydro-Flow Documentation
description: It's fun to say that I literally wrote the manual on municipal fire hydrant flow-control management software. This application was classic 90s-era business software: An MS Access database designed by a domain expert and jam-packed with visual basic. I had to learn an unexpected amount of hydrology math before I could tackle actually writing the documentation.

name: Advanced Surgical
description: What I really remember about this project is that I wrote a lot of gallbladder-related copy, and spent a ridiculous amount of time in Debabelizer trying to get print medical illustrations to look good as 16-color GIFs.

name: Howard Concrete
description: A surprisingly fun project for a local contractor that specialized in complex concrete work: historical fountain restoration, mall interiors, and so on.

name: Advantax
description: A local tax accounting firm that took the plunge into the web.

name: Fabbrini’s Flowers
description: A local florist went online in a big way, with a database-backed online "showroom" of gift bouquets. Believe it or not, Filemaker Pro was the web server on this one. The dotcom era saw a lot of wild and crazy ideas, but it was also an era when "order flowers on the internet!" was a novel value prop.

name: Retirement Resorts, Inc
description: Another big database-driven site; the world of hand-crafting everything was slowly being eclipsed as larger and laregr organizations realized the web was for real.

name: SermonBuilder
description: SermonBuilder was a bit like Amazon for beleagured megachurch pastorts. It took the prodigous sheet music, drama script, and sermon output of Willow Creek Community Church (a pioneer of media-heavy "seeker-sensitive" church services) and bundled it up for easy purchase and use by other congregations. While a high-flying consultancy managed the organization's infrastructure, I was hired to run its neglected web site and turn the pile of Perl scripts, loose Quicktime files, and ColdFusion scripts that had run SermonBuilder for years into a real ecommerce platform. By the time I left, the solo operation had grown to a team of three — all of us named Jeff.

name: DOW Agroscience
description: My first really large-scale enterprise project, in the waning days of the dotcom bubble. We took a custom DOS application that tracked every known use of the company's pesticides across the planet, and turned it into a web application that ran on Internet Explorer 45.0. Among other things, that let us use a cutting edge technique called "XML Data Islands" and client-side Javascript to speed up data-heavy interactions. Once XML over HTTP was supported by other browsers, this technique would eventually be konwn as "Every Web Page In The Universe."

name: The Chicago Board of Trade
description: Most of my work on this project boiled down to Lovecraftian parsing of MS Word files, which tells you a lot about how the Financial Services sector hasn’t changed.

name: Modern Abrasive
description: Industrial abrasives companies need web sites, too. I helped build them.

name: Concord Promotions
description: After the dotcom bubble collapsed, I did a bunch of freelance work, including some large database driven sites for my old employer, Robis. This one was a promotional products manufacturer: companies looking for conference swag or employee anniversary gifts could go online and have custom ones manufactured to spec.

name: Oak Enterprises
description: One of the interesting things about the "late early web" was the number of software consultancies that did big business building custom enterprise applications, but hadn't yet built a web team.

name: Cell phone billing automation
description: It is a truth universally acknowledged, that an entrerprise  in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of automation.

name: Prudential Real Estate
description: What Zillow now does, individual real estate agency companies used to do. I did the development work for an east coast realtor's site and learned a lot of painful lessons about early ASP.Net formstate limitations and the dangers of using SOAP as a cross-country SQL transport.

name: Drupal
description: Using Drupal for several of my side projects in early 2004 would end up changing the course of my career. I quickly became part of its surrounding Open Source community, squashing bugs and brainstorming new features with the project maintainers over IRC. Within a year I was maintaining popular plugin modules,, taking freelance development projects on the weekends, hammering out new parts of the project's core architecture, and writing documentation for new users. I joined one of the early Drupal consultancies, and spent a number of years as an active member of Drupal's core development team before refocusing on the content and information architecture challenges faced by our enterprise clients.

name: Daily Kos
description: Custom UGC moderation and promotion tools for DKos when it moved off of Scoop. https://www.drupal.org/project/latestgreatest was the result of this project.

name: EyesOnSales
description: Drupal build out, content migration, and launch. Built with a bleeding-edge version of Views.

name: MTV UK
description: Custom UGC moderation tools for the MTV UK site. Also ended up helping build out the advanced caching system along with Robert Douglas; memcached FTW. https://www.drupal.org/project/lovehate was the result of this project.

name: Tribal Football
description: Technical Analysis, Consulting

name: US Department of Commerce
description: Drupal training workshop

name: The City of Chicago
description: Consulting/Training

name: Infoworld
description: CMS Architecture & Consulting

name: The Industry Standard
description: Technical Analysis, Consulting

name: Seattle Times
description: CMS Architecture & Training

name: Fast Company Magazine
description: Architecture, custom editorial tools, and a migration pipeline for Fast Company's move from the FatWire CMS to Drupal.

name: Inc Magazine
description: Architecture, bespoke social networking features, custom editorial tools, and a migration pipeline for Inc. Magazine's move to Drupal.

name: 4FansSake
description: When a finance sector millionaire gets Zen and decides to change careers, sometimes he tries to buy the Chicago Cubs. We built his web site, and helped his team file the rough edges off of a social media campaign to accompany it. They were endearingly startled by the idea that sports fans on the internet might *argue* and *fight* in their message boards.

name: Ask A Ninja
description: Architecture and performance auditing for a viral sketch comedy project's community web site.

name: Zuda Comics
description: Architecture consulting and custom content production tools for Zuda Comics, DC Comics' first foray into direct digital publishing.

name: Chef Yum-Yum
description: User-friendly content creation tools  for Chef Yum Yum, a social recipe sharing site. Users could paste plaintext recipes from other web sites and message boards; My tools parsed out ingredients, units of measure, and other instructions into structured data for easy recipe conversions, allergy warnings, etc.

name: CSS Injector
description: A Drupal plugin module that allowed users to attach one-off CSS overrides to individual pages and posts. It started as a quick hack  to polish tutorial sites without introducing new users to the full complexity of Drupal theming, but became a popular plugin in its own right.

name: Buzzr
description: A SaaS website building platform based on Drupal. My work focused on user-friendly tools for building mixed trees of static and dynamic pages,, and a configuration management system that allowed the Buzzr product team to package complex Drupal configuration presets into reusable, packaged features for end users

name: Liquid Audio
description: Digital prize giveaway system for cross-brand promotion. Bottlecaps with free MP3 codes, etc.

name: Time Out New York
description: Technical Analysis, Consulting

name: Blittr
description: A terrible idea badly done

name: Stanford University
description: CMS Architecture

name: Lullabot Education Framework
description: Lullabot's training workshops produced a firehose of support assets. In the company's early years, each training event was planned from scratch. As demand for topical workshops and customized training packages grew, the ad-hoc approach became unsustainable. I consolidated our training support materials, developed a consistent framework for reusable teaching modules, and built internal curriculum management tools for each module's teaching notes and supporting assets.

name: Everywun
description: Content Architecture, Multisite architecture, API design, Business strategy

name: Arrayshift
description: A terrible idea badly done

name: Method
description: Technical Analysis, Consulting

name: Arizona State University
description: Consulting/Workshop

name: AAA
description: Consulting/Workshop

name: League of Legends Community Infrastructure
description: Scaling and architecture for player community tools

name: Spin Magazine
description: Technical Analysis, Consulting

name: Sony Pictures Television
description: CMS, Content architecture, Design Systems, Multisite

name: Harvard Extension School
description: CMS Architecture

name: Tizen Developer Documentation Portal
description: CMS and content architecture for community infrastructure and digital  documentation.

name: Mississippi State University
description: Multisite maintenance & content operations

name: Rackspace
description: Site architecture and content modeling

name: The Hollywood Reporter
description: Technical Analysis, Consulting

name: The NAMM Foundation
description: Content Audit, Modeling, Architecture

name: Swarthmore University
description: CMS architecture

name: Hotwire
description: Dynamic content assembly at scale

description: Content Strategy & Architecture Workshop

name: The University of Oklahoma
description: UO Libraries, Galileo’s World content

name: Harvard Extension School
description: Summer School, Careers, and more

name: SpaceX
description: Intranet IA, technical architecture, and strategy

name: Penguin-Random House Canada
description: CMS, Content Architecture, Content Strategy

name: Angie’s List
description: Scaling targeted content

name: EYP Architecture
description: Content and redesign

name: Harvard University
description: School Microsite Architecture

name: Davis-Polk
description: Consulting/Workshop

name: This Old House
description: Redesign, Content Strategy, CMS Architecture

name: Longboard Investments
description: Content and redesign

name: IBM Marketing
description: Global CMS Migration

name: NYU Langone University News Hub
description: CMS Replatforming

name: George Lucas Education Foundation
description: Headless CMS consultation

name: Somerset County Library System
description: Content Audit, Modeling, Architecture

name: Stanford Alumni Association
description: Decoupled Architecture

name: Carnegie Mellon University
description: CMS Evaluation, Site Audit

name: NAMM
description: NAMM.org and NAMM Show sites

name: IBM Watson/Cloud
description: Watson/Cloud CMS Architecture

name: Pantheon
description: Redesign, Content Strategy, Editorial Tooling

name: The State of Georgia
description: Strategy, Replatforming

name: MediaVillage
description: MediaVillage site redesign and replatforming

name: IBM Investor Relations
description: Investor Relations site redesign, replatforming

name: America Magazine
description: Content modeling and architecture workshop

name: Curriculum Associates
description: Content Strategy Workshop

name: IBM Cloud Marketing
description: I served as an embedded architect with the IBM Cloud Marketing team; notably, I developed a managable, maintainable system for producing niche product recommendation engines.

name: GatsbyJS
description: Product Consulting

name: IBM Global CMS Reboot
description: IBM's global .com site is a classic "seventeen companies in a trench coat" scenario. Using interviews, audits, and competitive analysis I helped their team develop a coherent organizational philosophy and navigation structure for their sprawling, frequently-overlapping mix of products, services, and solutions.

name: Carnegie Mellon University
description: CS School Content/CMS Audit

name: Evergreen College
description: Content & CMS Architecture

name: ElevenTufte
description: An 11ty starter kit based on Edward Tufte's information aesthetics.

name: The Cleveland Federal Reserve
description: Process & operations consulting

name: Charles Schwab
description: Content Architecture & Design Systems

name: Home Depot
description: Responsive & Multichannel Workshop

name: John Deere
description: Product Data Architecture

name: Tableau Software
description: IA, Content Architecture, Competitive Auditing & Analysis, CMS Architecture

name: Pantheon
description: Product Consulting

name: Target
description: Content Architecture, Design System, Org Doctrine

name: Contento
description: Product Consulting

name: Dropbox
description: Site Consolidation Strategy

name: BonusFinder
description: Responsive design and content architecture bootcamp for an online gaming startup.

name: Module Monday
description: A weekly column for the Lullabot.com site, highlighting new and noteworthy Drupal plugins.

name: Dancing Queen
description: A ePub-to-11ty migration tool for abandoned A Book Apart authors.
